p:
Many definitions have been used in the literature to quantify the WAM onset date
39 , i.e. the rapid latitudinal shift of the precipitation maximum from 5°N to about 10°N at the end of June/early July. To capture the large-scale shift of the precipitation band we closely follow the approach from Fontaine and Louvet
40 and Vellinga et al.
6 and define two rainfall indices of zonally averaged precipitation between 10°W to 10°E, one southern index from the equator to 7.5°N and a northern index from 7.5°N to 20°N. Both indices are smoothed with a 15-day low-pass filter and normalized by their respective standard deviations to reduce the influence of mean-state biases in the coupled models. The onset is defined as the first day after 1 June where the northern index exceeds the southern index for at least 15 consecutive days, or for the longest period in years that have no clear onset.
